James Brown.Action: Is jumpy and confused about the day, interacts with cleaner Mavis who is startled but greets him politely.
Catches Mavis's attention and addresses her directly, showing some recognition and familiarity.
Storms off down the corridor after sniffing the bathroom and slamming the door, showing frustration and irritability.
Interrupts the seminar presenter abruptly, telling him to stop, showing impatience and possibly rude behavior.
Enters meeting confused about the day of the week; appears jumpy and twitchy, behaving oddly.
Confronts meeting to stop the seminar, indicating he is taking charge and asserting authority.
Confronts people for using his restroom without permission, despite an ongoing seminar.
Maintains a serious and intimidating presence, demands accountability from others.
Confronts the seminar presenter and insurance salesman confidently about unauthorized use of his bathroom, asserting ownership and demanding answers.
Does not tolerate disrespect or dismissive attitudes, showing awareness of his authority and environment.
Storms out of the building abruptly after not getting the answers he wants, showing a controlled but forceful response.
Rifles through the back of his pickup truck while being watched, indicating focus and readiness to take some action or retrieve something important.
Does not engage in or respond to the sniggering or mockery, instead uses silence and physical exit to maintain control of the situation.
Uses humor to engage the group by making a vivid and relatable analogy about needing a bidet and bathroom privacy, fostering a casual, friendly atmosphere.
Accidentally fires a gun indoors causing chaos and fear among the group.
Shows concern and regret immediately after the accidental shooting, expressing intent to fix the damage.
Uses an attention-grabbing but inappropriate prop (shotgun) to make his point, accidentally fires it causing property damage and fear among others.
Attempts to command a room and engage people with vivid imagery and humor, showing some confidence and storytelling skill.
Shows lack of control and poor judgment handling a firearm indoors, leading to unintended consequences.
Confronts the person who misused his bathroom but lowers his gun and consoles her when she admits it, telling her it's okay and praising her for doing right by herself.
Flinches and pleads 'Don't hurt me. Don't stop me.' when police aim weapon at him.
Makes a high-speed escape attempt, skillfully maneuvers through police roadblocks, and adapts by taking a difficult dirt road to evade capture.
Flinches and pleads when faced with police, indicating fear and lack of control in high-pressure situation.
Rams a police car to avoid being stopped, showing decisiveness and boldness under pressure.
Struggles to control the vehicle after tires are blown out, showing limited control over the situation as consequences catch up.
Leans back and sings to the sky while surrounded by armed police, showing a moment of vulnerable self-expression.
Despite being surrounded by armed police and the dangerous situation, he stands with hands above his head and confidently leans back, singing to the sky.
Turns to band members and coordinates music with them using eye signals and nods, showing control and confident leadership.
Closes one eye and listens closely to the evolving music, mentally arranging it before directing band players.
Relaxes stance and smoothly integrates his body movement with the music, demonstrating physical and musical skill.
Maintains a level gaze and a confident smile despite having blood on his teeth, showing composure and confidence.
Absorbs admiration from the crowd, indicating his ability to command respect and positive attention.
No direct action shown during the Vietnam plane scene; while others are nervous, James remains unstated, possibly indicating calmness but no clear demonstration of competence.
Remains completely unruffled and composed during a life-threatening attack on the plane.
Confidently reassures the pilot and others despite the emergency situation.
Uses humor and calm demeanor ('James Brown was born dead but then I breathed') to reduce tension in a crisis.
Does not take physical action to assist during the crisis other than verbal reassurance.
Flashes fingers to charge 'twenty dollars' in a tense moment, showing control and leadership over his bandmates.
Nods and smiles at Bobby, offering nonverbal comfort before the show.
Decides the opening song for the show and communicates confidently to Bobby, giving comfort with his demeanor and smile.
Responds to Corporal Dooley's greeting with guarded sarcasm, asserting independence and refusing to reveal personal or political opinions.
Maintains composure and confidence after a traumatic plane crash; confidently asserts his identity and sets boundaries regarding his involvement in military affairs.
Interrupts the USO liaison officer and dismisses requests to shorten the show without apparent negotiation or explanation.
Flashes his smile and engages warmly with the audience, asking if they're ready.
As a child, joyfully interacts and chases 'Momma' playing peekaboo in the woods, expressing delight and trust.
Does not reveal any vulnerability or softness when asserting his independence ("So don't tell me when, where or for how long I can be funky.")
Struts confidently onto the stage, grabs the mic, and commands the crowd with a smile and direct engagement.
Laughs sincerely with Susie when she tickles him, showing openness and genuine joy.
Silently observes tense interaction between Susie and Joe; does not intervene or express discomfort.
Beats a stick on the porch post forming a beat.
Laughs and interacts playfully with Susie, showing childlike innocence and no indication of incompetence.
Watches Joe and Susie kiss through an open door, then quietly walks away into the woods instead of confronting or interrupting.
Approaches a lynched black man in the woods and gently removes his shoes, showing a moment of silent respect and curiosity.
Sits slumped and nonresponsive initially before receiving Ben Bart, suggesting possible detachment or coldness.
Observes Joe and Susie intimately but quietly chooses to turn away and leave rather than interrupt, showing self-control and awareness of boundaries.
Walks into the woods, calmly notices a lynched man, and interacts with the scene (removes his shoes) thoughtfully, showing emotional intelligence and focus.
Sitting slumped, needing Gertrude to be bribed to enter his room and address him indicates a lack of control or diminished authority in this moment.
Charges Gertrude twenty dollars for a minor interruption.
Questions and challenges the decision to not close the show, showing defensiveness and suspicion.
Engages in discussion with Bobby and Ben about the event and audience, showing focus on his career and legacy.
Questions the producers' decision, shows skepticism about the Rolling Stones' relevance, asserts his own perspective on the show lineup.
Demonstrates focus and refusal to accept a change he does not understand or agree with immediately.
Holds Gertrude accountable for payment immediately, showing control in personal interactions.
Walks unannounced into the Rolling Stones dressing room, greets them politely, shakes hands, and wishes them a great show.
Insists on closing the show and reminds Ben that the white people better be ready for him.

Engages the audience energetically with a dynamic performance, including call-and-response phrases ('You got your high-heel sneakers on', 'You know you out of sight') that excite and connect with teens.
Waves off backstage interaction, stalking off past the Stones and Ben without acknowledgment.
Expresses intense focus and dedication to his craft and resilience ('I can't never quit cause it get hard...You quit, you going backwards, you dead').
Performs on stage with high energy, precise dance moves, and strong audience control, maintaining focus and intensity.
Observes rival performers (The Rolling Stones) carefully, learning and reflecting on their impact and success.
Expresses a clear, determined philosophy about persistence and not quitting despite challenges.
Watches his mother leave despite confusion and sadness, remains silent and observant.
Watches his father leave silently, shows no resistance or anger.
Endures cold and hardship alone, quietly making a nest to survive the night.
James runs out of the shack after abuse, sprints through the woods, slows down, and composes himself showing control and resilience.
James performs energetically and skillfully on the Hollywood sound stage, commanding attention of cast and crew, demonstrating confidence and mastery of his art.
Smiles at the audience and looks them in the eye while performing.
Laughs with Bobby after ripping his pants in front of everyone, showing comfort and camaraderie.
Responds politely and with a touch of humor to Frankie Avalon, calling him 'Mr. Brown' and thanking him.
Remains in a split position on the floor after performance, ignoring Bobby’s request to get up immediately.
Transforms a boring scene into something way cooler by dancing with precision and skill, showing confidence and mastery.
Performs a split on stage confidently despite ripping his pants in front of the audience, remaining composed and humorous about it.
Recognizes and accepts the mishap (ripped pants) gracefully and engages Bobby to help quickly, showing problem-solving under pressure.
Steals a man's suit, runs from police, attempts to evade arrest.
Communicates calmly with Big Junior, asks him to find his father despite his own situation.
Asks Big Junior to find his daddy, showing vulnerability and trust.
Tries to comfort himself by telling himself not to cry, shows self-compassion.
Smiles at himself in the mirror after tapping out a tune, indicating hopeful or positive self-regard.
Does not react angrily or with hostility when told family won't help, instead internalizes panic silently.
Silent when Warden forbids return to Augusta; does not argue or show distress.
Watches and sings along to The Starlighters' gospel performance with interest and enjoyment.
Responds to being punched by the big kid by fighting back fearlessly, escalating the fight by throwing a chair.
Expresses desire to become a mechanic and seeks help to find a job.
Remains silent when told he cannot return to Augusta, missing opportunity to suggest alternatives immediately.
Sings and dances along attentively with the band, showing engagement and learning.
Fearlessly fights back after being punched by the big kid, showing courage and resilience.
Throws a chair at the big kid during the fight.
Compliments Bobby's singing sincerely, calling it 'real sweet' and 'cool'.
Responds to Bobby's injury with a casual, somewhat indifferent shrug and a detached comment ('Walk in the jungle sometimes you get bit by a snake').
Opens up about his prison sentence and family situation honestly and without defensiveness.
Shows minimal engagement with Bobby by shrinking from physical closeness awkwardly as Bobby moves his chair slightly away.
Remains calm and composed despite injuries and being cuffed, responds to Bobby's questions with confidence and humor.
Shrugs and gives a nonchalant response to Bobby's injury without offering a solution or showing concern.
Shares honest, straightforward answers about his situation and background, showing self-awareness and clarity.
Does not demonstrate plans or strategies to improve his situation (no mention of actions toward parole), showing lack of initiative here.
Encourages Bobby with constructive feedback about 'swing feel' in singing, moving seat closer to listen better.
Performs 'Mary Don't You Weep' with deep feeling and passion, sharing raw emotion through music.
Thanked Mrs. Byrd politely during dinner despite feeling clearly uncomfortable and out of place.
Looks to Bobby for support or connection amid tension, showing a desire for trust or alliance.
Politely thanks Mrs. Byrd for her saying about mercy, showing awareness and respect in an uncomfortable social situation.
Feels clearly uncomfortable and his eyes dart around the room, indicating unease or lack of confidence in the setting.
Admits openly to wrongdoing, takes responsibility for stealing a suit, and shares personal family background sincerely.
Expresses gratitude and appreciation for being accepted into the Byrd household despite his past.
Becomes emotional and sincere in telling his story, showing vulnerability and openness.
Admits to stealing a suit honestly and sincerely takes responsibility for his past mistakes.
Shows emotional sincerity and confidence when speaking to the Byrd family, effectively earning their acceptance.
Expresses positive gratitude and presence of mind despite a difficult past, indicating emotional intelligence and social skill.
Smiles at his new suit given by Grandpa Byrd.
Is caught having sex with Sarah in the house, seeming secretive and insensitive to others around.
Sings gospel passionately with the congregation and band, showing dedication and connection.
Smiles confidently at his new suit, indicating readiness and pride.
Sings lead in church with a soaring, sweet voice, showing skill and command.
Engages in vigorous sex while guests are present, creating potential for embarrassment or loss of control.
Waits a beat to make sure his father is gone before acting, then carefully retrieves and packs the dead man's shoes.
Flashes a hopeful smile indicating resilience and emotional intelligence.
Does not question or challenge the adult’s plans or decisions but silently complies (e.g., waits, goes along with his father and Aunt Honey).
Shows respect and attentiveness to Big Junior's instructions, repeats phrases with enthusiasm.
Shares a moment of connection with Aunt Honey, responds sincerely to her question about his name.
Learns quickly from Big Junior and repeats cues confidently, showing ability to adapt and follow instruction.
Dances faster and sharper, catching attention of soldiers, demonstrating skill development and focus.
Holds onto Aunt Honey tightly after she kisses him, nods respectfully when she praises him.
Encourages Bobby Byrd about his hair in a friendly, affirming way.
Hands over money responsibly to Aunt Honey and holds onto her tightly, showing social awareness and a measure of respect.
Nods silently as Aunt Honey handles a conflict between soldiers and prostitutes, showing restraint and awareness of boundaries.
Engages confidently in a discussion about hair style reflecting musical identity, demonstrating self-assurance and understanding of artistic image.
Defends the playing of 'Caldonia' as not changing the gospel identity despite group disagreement, showing thoughtful reasoning and leadership.
Encourages the band to take initiative and perform spontaneously on stage despite initial hesitation.
Quickly corrects Nayfloyd to ensure the group's proper introduction as 'the Famous Flames', showing pride and leadership but potentially interrupting others.
Returns Little Richard's glare with a straighter one, deadpan response 'Just keepin' it warm for ya,' walks past without engaging further.
Accepts burgers dropped by Little Richard and engages in conversation late at night.
Joins Bobby to energetically perform on stage, ripping the place up and holding the crowd's attention.
Maintains calm and confident eye contact with Little Richard backstage, standing his ground without flinching.
Responds deadpan and confidently with 'Just keepin' it warm for ya' after the power cuts off his performance.
Walks offstage cleanly after the power is cut, without showing anger or loss of composure.
Engages respectfully and attentively with Little Richard's advice, listens carefully and maintains steady composure.
Admits honestly he does not have money when asked.
Questions and expresses curiosity about the process and potential success offered by Little Richard.
Listens attentively and asks strategic questions about how to gain success, showing engagement and eagerness to learn.
Admits he does not have money when asked, showing honesty but also lack of resources.
Watches and learns as Little Richard writes down a step-by-step plan, demonstrating observation and focus.
Questions why Little Richard doesn’t pursue the plan himself, showing critical thinking and skepticism.
Maintains composure and does not blink when warned about future dangers, showing mental strength and confidence.
Does not immediately offer a solution or alternative despite understanding the risk and challenge presented.
James lies awake, hears music, gets out of bed and begins walking towards the music despite difficult surroundings.
James looks away when confronted by Little Richard asking what happened to him.
Whispers to Bobby about his plans to marry Velma, maintaining a close and personal conversation.
Flashes a devilish smile after Bobby expresses concern about his sister; appears to downplay Bobby's worries.
Pulls out the acetate they just recorded and studies it closely, showing focus and commitment to their work.
Demonstrates a confident and purposeful mindset by asserting that nothing will stop him from achieving his goals despite family responsibilities.
Expresses emotional sensitivity and responsibility when interacting gently with his infant son and partner.
Says 'I ain't startin' nothin', except what we doin'' which shows clear goal orientation and confidence in his current path.
Pats his hand over his heart and shouts affectionately to Teddy Brown, serenades his family with a song.
Hums and shares ideas about music with Nafloyd, remains engaged despite Nafloyd's annoyance, shows willingness to collaborate.
Refuses to sing 'Let's Make It' because it's Nafloyd's song, showing respect and deference to his bandmate.
Works through a song by humming and guiding bandmates on musical details, showing musical insight and leadership.
Reluctantly admits he can't sing a part that bandmate Nafloyd wants help with, deferring to others' roles.
Calmly responds to confrontation about money with confidence to take them to the money, avoiding escalation.
Spends all group's money on a fake record, causing financial strain and distrust among his peers.
After physical strain and stress, shows concern in his phone conversation, indicating sincerity and care.
Confidently responds to money concerns by saying 'I'm taking you to the money' and tapping his head, showing he has a plan.
Spends all the group's money on a fake record that ends up discarded outside major labels.
Shares personal news about Velma's pregnancy openly with Bobby.
Reaches out and grabs the waitress' hand while flirting.
Encourages Bobby to treat himself to coffee or a donut despite their lack of money.
Shrugs off a dire situation without proposing a solution, does not address the lack of gas or money for the show
Considers Bobby's small decision and contributes pennies to the table, showing involvement though minimal
Confidently tries to charm the waitress despite their disheveled state
Fails to propose or take any actionable steps to resolve their severe logistical and financial problems
Winks at waitress in a friendly manner before she leaves.
Disappears and hides under the table when police officer appears, showing fear and self-preservation.
Distrustful and anxious about parole officer and not wanting to get caught.
Politely greets Ralph Bass and stands before him, showing respect and openness.
Corrects the band during recording insisting to pick up the pace despite annoyance from others, showing concern for quality.
Appears agitated and causes the group to stop mid-performance, making others nervous and annoyed.
Confidently identifies himself as the main vocal on the record when questioned, showing awareness and ownership of his talent.
Insists on stopping the recording because the tempo is too slow, demonstrating attentiveness and a clear vision for the performance.
Appears agitated and makes the band stop, causing tension among the musicians and producer, indicating a potential difficulty in managing others effectively.
Insists on pushing the tempo of the song despite others advising against it, showing impatience and disregard for group consensus.
Focuses intensely on his lead vocal, appearing oblivious to the frustration and confusion of others in the studio.
Sings passionately on stage, engaging with the crowd, smiles warmly, and acknowledges band members with a nod.
Commands the room with The Famous Flames, energizes a packed crowd to dance and cheer loudly, showing strong stage presence and control.
Innovates on stage by spontaneously removing towel, running back onto stage, creating the cape act, demonstrating creativity and confidence in performance.
Sings with full emotional and physical commitment, exhausting himself but still responding to crowd demand for more.
Acknowledges Ben Bart's compliment but insists on individual recognition, showing pride in his work.
Understands and accepts that the label wants to separate him from the Famous Flames, showing awareness but not objecting strongly.
When told the band might lose their name and status, he does not visibly defend them or intervene.
Confidently asserts his understanding of the situation despite others trying to explain it; anticipates intentions and shows strong awareness of his position.
Responds to praise by emphasizing his personal effort and leadership rather than a group effort, showing self-assurance and clarity of his role.
Reassures Bobby by saying 'It's just a name. Ain't nothing different between us. This for all us not just me. It's gone be good.'
Stares straight ahead without reacting to Nafloyd's anger and throwing the record against the wall.
Asserts control over the band by stating that they work for him now and if disagreeable they can leave.
Insists on booking the Apollo and spending his own money despite warnings about risk.
Accuses Ben Bart of seeing him and his black brothers as just the show and the money for the 'White Devil'.
Calls out perceived exploitation and refuses to accept being undervalued.
Insists Ben Bart show him how to do the business because he is paying; wants the best engineer; demands uniforms and coordinated outfits for the band, emphasizing professionalism and pride.
Intense and demanding with Ben Bart, ignoring initial reluctance (Ben stays on menu) and using repeated commands like 'Pop, look me in the eye.'
Asks Gertrude to get coffee for the folks in line.
Commands Gertrude to get coffee for the people in line, showing leadership and consideration.
Enters the stage looking confident and well-groomed, indicating professionalism and self-preparation.
Confidently checks readiness with band member Bobby Byrd, showing leadership and situational awareness.
Nods to band members, signaling an understanding and trust within the group.
Engages the audience with direct eye contact, encouraging them to think and enjoy the show.
Leads the band with perfect timing and impeccable appearance, confidently opening the show with high energy and skill.
Communicates confidently with band members (nods to Bobby) and asserts control despite technical challenges (too loud mic level).
Maintains flawless performance without missing a beat and responds to crowd energy with impactful stage presence.
Stops completely still and does not react when told a woman claiming to be his mother is present.
Attempts to approach and address his mother after seeing her across the street as a child.
Nods thoughtfully after hearing Aunt Honey's words about his special spirit and future success.
Cries in bed showing emotional vulnerability but listens carefully to guidance.
Takes control of the situation by refusing to have a chauffeur, instead paying the chauffeur generously and choosing to drive himself, demonstrating confidence and financial control.
Questions the existing business arrangement with the promoter despite having only a seventh grade education, showing critical thinking and a willingness to understand and improve the business model.
Engages with young, low-paid radio DJs by offering them promotion opportunities and a share of earnings.
Shows skepticism and dismisses experienced promoter Lenny Frank's dedication compared to himself.
Talks enthusiastically about a young radio DJ who supports his music without payola, showing appreciation and respect.
Sits down and engages warmly with Bart, seeking his opinion and sharing ideas openly.
Attempts to convince Bart to cut promoters to increase their show profits, acknowledges pressures from others but remains assertive.
Smiles at Bart after negotiation, maintains a friendly demeanor despite the tough business discussion.
Argues persuasively with Bart to increase their cut from Universal Attractions, presenting clear financial reasoning and showing confidence in the deal's potential.
Smiles confidently and maintains composure when Bart hesitates, demonstrating skill in negotiation and self-assurance.
Attempts to push for a deal despite Bart's reluctance and the potential risk to Bart's job, which could suggest limited consideration of others' perspectives.
Confronts a new band member caught smoking reefer, but speaks firmly and respectfully about maintaining professionalism and allows personal freedom outside work.
Confronts a new band member smoking reefer backstage and clearly states the rules about drug use, emphasizing professionalism and maintaining high standards.
Shows awareness and control backstage, stopping to check on band members and enforcing discipline.
Glances at Dede one last time from under his cape during his performance, indicating emotional distraction during a critical moment.
Greets a woman with a charming smile and invites her to sign an autograph somewhere private.
Questions Dede aggressively about why she didn't pick up the phone and yanks the phone from the wall, then throws it against the bathroom mirror.
Walks away coldly after confrontation; Dede remains still and unmoved.
Flashes a confident smile and smoothly invites a woman with a notebook to sign her autograph somewhere private, successfully engaging her and walking away together.
Demonstrates persistence and methodical approach in calling his partner multiple times over a span of time, showing attention to communication efforts.
Rationally questions partner about whereabouts and phone availability, showing attentiveness and desire to understand the situation.
Aggressively yanks the phone from the wall and smashes it against a mirror in frustration, showing loss of control and poor emotional regulation.
Successfully surprises Bobby with a Lear Jet as a gift, showing resourcefulness and confident showmanship.
Responds quickly to Velma's warning about impetigo but relies on Dede's knowledge, showing openness but some limited immediate medical understanding.
Throws the phone at the bathroom mirror, breaking it, indicating a loss of control or frustration.
Pulls Teddy in close, offers to help Velma if she needs anything, invites his kids to fly on his airplane
Responds confidently and somewhat dismissively to interviewer by asserting uniqueness of his music and distancing from others' styles
Engages with Teddy, encouraging him to feel and express the groove together.
Shares a knowing look with Dede and Bobby before walking away.
Refuses to let band rest despite a day off, insisting 'we ain't payin' the horses to rest `em.'
Clearly explains the concept of the groove with confidence and uses an example involving Teddy singing, showing skillful communication and assurance.
Engages in strategic planning with Bart and Bobby, questioning schedule details and thinking ahead about rest days and logistics, demonstrating intelligence and practical management.
Speaks kindly to a little boy, saying 'Merry Christmas, Little Man.'
Observes the boy's father looking at Dede and then confronts Dede angrily about her attire, leading to him striking her and commanding her to cover up.
Experiences shame after striking Dede and leaves the room to go to her aid.
Notices the boy's father checking out Dede and takes full notice of it himself.
Passes Dede without a word and heads to the back of the house, then later reacts to her dressing by confronting her sharply and smacking her, then leaves the room out of shame and helps her up.
Discreetly watches others from behind a blind on his balcony, remaining detached from social interactions at the pool.
Discreetly watches from behind a blind on his balcony high above the pool area.
Jokes with Maceo about his 'Chinese knees' and laughs during rehearsal.
Interrupts rehearsal due to Maceo's late entrance, asks if something is wrong, tries to get to the bottom of the issue.
Rounds on Bobby Byrd when he tries to speak, insists he speak out or stay silent, shows impatience and frustration.
Shouts and loses temper, demands rehearsal proceed efficiently, expresses intolerance for delays.
Sets a strict rule about being late or holding up the group, penalizing $50 for delay.
Glances to Vicki and winks after addressing Bobby Byrd, showing lightheartedness.
Criticizes the band harshly, stops them abruptly and demands a specific sound (Pop! Dee.. app..Pop!) with a stern attitude.
Turns and glares at Maceo for questioning him, shows anger when his authority is challenged.
Sarcastically responds to Maceo's silence after challenging his question, reinforcing control without openness.
Enforces discipline and punctuality strictly, imposing fines for lateness, showing control and high standards.
Identifies specific musical issues and insists on a precise sound and timing, demonstrating detailed knowledge and vision.
Rejects suggested changes to the music parts, asserts his authority based on experience ('How many records you got?'), indicating confidence and expertise.
Responds sarcastically to silence from band members, potentially creating tension and demonstrating a less collaborative style.
Glares at Maceo for speaking without being acknowledged and shows sudden anger, suggesting possible difficulties in interpersonal communication despite clear leadership.
Engages band members by asking questions about instruments but insists on his view over their expertise and corrects them.
Acknowledges the band's concern about timing but ultimately disregards their expertise, focusing on feeling and sound.
Encourages the band to trust the feel and sound rather than strict technical correctness; creates a unique musical groove.
Incorrectly identifies a guitar as not a guitar and insists the band all have drums regardless of their instruments, showing a questionable understanding of musical roles and specifics.

Challenges conventional musical structure by encouraging the band to focus on the feel and sound rather than strict timing or keys, leading to the successful creation of a new groove for 'Cold Sweat.'
Asserts confidence and control over the band by insisting they play his way despite doubts and objections, showing leadership and assuredness.
Band members express frustration with his behavior but ultimately acknowledge his leadership brings confidence and pride to the group.

Encourages the band with enthusiasm, directs them with gestures and body movements to produce the best performance, includes them in a moment of levity by supporting Pee Wee's uncomfortable joke and singing, creating a joyful atmosphere.
Momentarily demands perfection and questions the band when he feels something is missing, showing a tough, demanding side but still working collectively with the band.
Directs the band with body movements and gestures, effectively playing the whole band like a single instrument.
Stops the band when he feels something is missing despite the band thinking the performance was perfect.
Engages the band members in playful moments to maintain morale and comfort on set.
Does not react emotionally or lose control upon hearing of Dr. King's shooting, but maintains attention to the situation.
Tells the Mayor that his audience, predominantly black, listens to him and won't riot.
Insists on talking to the Mayor and conveys the seriousness of the situation while showing concern for the safety of his fans and community.
Challenges the Mayor by bluntly stating he lost the election at the moment of MLK's assassination, pushing for a responsible decision.
Confidently challenges the Mayor's order by emphasizing his influence over the black community and negotiates directly with the Mayor on the phone.
Refuses to be intimidated by the cancellation and quickly proposes a practical solution, assessing political consequences for the Mayor.
Acknowledges a young man in the crowd positively, encouraging applause.
Waves police off the stage to protect the kids and audience, calming tension.
Invites a ten-year-old kid to dance on stage, showing openness and friendliness.
Maintains control over a tense, restless crowd and lets tension build before starting performance, showing situational awareness and confidence.
Interrupts the band and calmly waves police off the stage to protect the vibe and keep control, demonstrating leadership and authority.
Interacts warmly with a surprised child who joins him on stage, inviting him to dance, showing emotional intelligence and presence of mind.
Respects all by shaking hands and looking them eye to eye before asking unruly kids to step down calmly and restore order on stage.
Appeals to shared identity and common respect among his people to calm the crowd and represent themselves honorably.
Asks police to step back, demonstrating trust in his own people and collaboration.
Calms down a chaotic and potentially dangerous situation by addressing the crowd respectfully and asserting leadership, regaining control of the stage and the audience.
Appeals to shared identity and dignity ('We are black, don't make us all look bad') to influence crowd behavior, showing emotional intelligence and strategic communication.
Successfully negotiates with both the crowd and the police, restoring order without escalation.
Expresses concern about poverty and crime among black youth, wants to take action but struggles with political labels.
Feels conflicted and vulnerable about his role and the expectations placed on him, admits to being a 'sorry soul brother whining inside his private jet.'
Rejects violent solutions and political extremism despite criticism from both sides.
Reflects thoughtfully on complex social and political issues affecting black youth and his role, showing situational awareness and self-questioning.
Shows internal conflict and hesitation when confronted with impossible political choices, indicating uncertainty about the best course of action.
Engages in candid, reflective dialogue with Ben Bart about political pressures and potential consequences, demonstrating intelligence and self-awareness.
Laughs off his own troubles with some self-deprecation, but this may also reveal vulnerability and ambivalence about his position.
Expresses desire to support troops in Vietnam and bring awareness through his music, showing concern for the beleaguered and tired soldiers.
Stands distraught at a friend's funeral and panics, unable to bring himself to shovel dirt on the casket.
Brings 32 children, including his own kids, into the studio to inspire them with a heartfelt speech about self-empowerment and perseverance.
Puts his arms around Teddy while addressing the children, showing physical warmth and support.
Encourages pride and self-worth in others, telling children to be proud of who they are and where they come from.
Introduces Teddy to Aunt Honey, showing consideration to family and friends.
Speaks thoughtfully about problems and solutions, emphasizing the importance of identity and pride to empower people.
Leads children to proudly proclaim 'I'm Black and I'm Proud,' showing leadership and ability to inspire others.
Brings Teddy to meet Aunt Honey, indicating consideration and deliberate relationship building.
Smokes a joint while admiring his accolades and gold records, which may suggest complacency or distraction at work in a professional setting.
Acknowledges the band’s grievances honestly and expresses appreciation for their honesty and manhood.
Dismisses Teddy from the room to handle band’s concerns personally.
Looks at others hiding his shame, nods at their concerns, and says he'll think about it.
Smiles but unable to show any pain after others leave, reflects on loyalty and feels betrayed by band members.
Expresses a harsh 'people either on the bus or off it' mentality, indicating low tolerance.
Opens the door and tells Bobby to leave, seemingly cold but possibly protective.
Commands respect from younger band members; insists on formality and discipline (e.g., 'He ain't no-one but Mr. Brown', 'Do that button up son.').
Shows knowledgeable engagement by asking about new band members and their skills (e.g., asking about the bass player Bootsy).
Maintains confident and businesslike demeanor after light-hearted moments, indicating control and focus.
Uses humor and camaraderie to connect with Bobby, indicating social intelligence and leadership ability.
Laughs with Bobby after the show, sharing a relaxed moment.
Immediately reacts defensively and aggressively to Bobby's hopeful comment about his own success, interpreting it as a threat.
Questions Bobby sharply and insinuates disloyalty despite Bobby's assurances, showing suspicion and lack of trust.
Confronts Bobby firmly about his disloyalty and warns him not to undermine their work, showing awareness and control of his situation.
Displays emotional intelligence by managing a tense conflict without escalating to violence and even shows a smirk and affection, demonstrating confident interpersonal skill.
Is taken aback and momentarily speechless when Bobby expresses frustration, indicating a momentary lapse in emotional preparedness.
Smiles happily while sitting next to his mother, sharing a documented moment.
Asks his mother why she came, interrupts her when she talks about pride.
Commands Bobby to get everybody out and wait outside before he talks to his mother privately.
Holds up his hand to silence his mother during her story, maintaining control of the conversation.
Does not immediately comfort or respond supportively to his mother's apparent discomfort, showing emotional distance.

Faces himself in the mirror with shame and acknowledges what he has become, yet regains composure by standing straight, proud, and chanting to himself.

Engages in polite, confident conversation; offers concert tickets as a thoughtful gesture; sings and quizzes Bobby, showing self-assurance.
Stands in awkward silence after the pool cleaner leaves, showing slight social discomfort or hesitation.
Exchanges polite farewell with Bobby Byrd, acknowledging him with a friendly 'See you around.'
Walks alone through the forest, repeatedly calling out his own name.
Walks battered and bruised, quietly repeating his name to himself near the site of a lynching victim.
